executive_summary: Renowned for its vibrant flavors and healthful attributes, Mediterranean cuisine centers around fresh fruits, vegetables, whole grains, olive oil, and lean proteins like fish and legumes. Mediterranean restaurants experienced volatility in the last few years because of domestic and global economic changes. When the pandemic hit, many restaurant owners were forced to curtail dine-in operations, contributing to a massive dip in revenue in 2020, though an uptick in take-away order sustained many establishments during this time. Recovery was swift, once the government lifted stay-at-home orders, leaving consumers eager to eat out again. Rising consumer spending throughout the last few years has been a driver behind a rise in consumer expenditures on dining out. Demand for Mediterranean cuisine has grown.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Fast Casual Dining Model Takes Over the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of Mediterranean restaurants has grown rapidly over the past decade, as Mediterranean and Middle Eastern cuisines have become increasingly popular. This growth has primarily been driven by the introduction of Mediterranean food to the fast casual dining restaurant model. Grain bowls and pita wraps can be prepared quickly, with various protein and veggie options available for customers to choose from. These meals are made of nutritious ingredients and are a healthier alternative to fast food.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Post-Pandemic Recovery Saw a Rise in Consumer Spending
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: For these reasons, growth has been concentrated in metropolitan areas, particularly near large commercial centers, because fast casual restaurants benefit from the daily lunch rush. Mediterranean restaurants experienced strong growth until 2020, when the industry took a hit due to the pandemic. Cities and states imposed stay-at-home orders prohibiting in-person dining and required nonessential businesses to keep employees at home. Without demand from office-goers, many fast casual industry companies generated less revenue. Since the pandemic, many employees have returned to work in offices, revenue experienced a significant recovery period in 2021 as many offices returned to in-person operations. Consumer spending has grown since the height of the pandemic, as pent-up demand has left people eager to spend on fast casual and full-service dining.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Latest Food Trends Celebrate Multi-Cultural Cuisines
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers with a taste for international cuisine seek out flavorful and exotic meals, like those available in Mediterranean restaurants. Gen Z and Millennial consumers are particularly adventurous in their preferences, but need to be discerning about what they pay to ensure they are not spending outside their means. Some cuisines originating in the Mediterranean region, like Italian and Greek, have been quite popular for years. Familiarity is important to consumers that don't wish to step out of their comfort zones. Other cuisines, like Egyptian, Lebanese and Turkish food are emerging as popular options for consumers looking to experience something new and different.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As Mediterranean and Middle Eastern cuisine become more popular, restaurants are likely to begin growing outside of cities and entering suburban and rural communities. Despite this moderate expansion this growth will likely be slower than that of the previous five-year period as many areas with demand for Mediterranean food already have restaurants serving them. Over the next five years, Mediterranean restaurants are likely to follow a similar pattern to other food service industries that benefited from a surge in fast casual dining. The market will reach a point of saturation and restaurants will struggle against increased competition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mediterranean Restaurants Will Accommodate Newly Turned Vegans and Vegetarians
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Veganism is becoming increasingly mainstream, and new vegans and vegetarians will find that basic Mediterranean cuisine fits in well with these

The use of plant-based alternatives to meat is predicted to be a top food trend moving forward. While veggie-centric dishes have always been common, innovations is meat substitutes are bound to make their way to Mediterranean menus. With a greater emphasis on sustainability, there will be a growing interest in locally sourced, eco-friendly ingredients in the Mediterranean food scene.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry primarily sell Mediterranean food and beverages for restaurant dining or takeout.
key_trends: High initial capital investment in quality ingredients and skilled staff, coupled with intense competition in the food service market, make entry difficult for Mediterranean. Establishing a unique identity in a saturated market amidst comparable establishments can be a significant challenge.
Suppliers wield considerable influence on Mediterranean restaurants, influencing menu offerings and the output of a restaurant. Mediterranean restaurants rely on consistent delivery of
Mediterranean restaurants rely on fresh fish and produce, as the quality and authenticity of ingredients directly impacts a restaurant's success.

Exploring home-cooked Mediterranean recipes allows for creative control and customization, offering an authentic experience with healthier ingredient choices and cost savings. Japanese cuisine offers many similar opportunities for healthy eating, since, like Mediterranean food, it emphasizes the use of fish and vegetables.

Over the five years to 2024, Mediterranean Restaurants industry revenue has benefited from increased consumer spending and disposable income. Thanks to its affordability and nutritional value, Mediterranean food has become a staple in many American's diets.

Looking ahead, the food and health landscape appears poised for dynamic shifts, and these changes will undoubtedly influence Mediterranean cuisine. A rise in the popularity of vegetarian and vegan diets, along with greater disposable income, will contribute to consistent demand over the next few years.
Private assistance for Mediterranean restaurants includes grants or loans from culinary organizations or foundations aiming to support small businesses in the food sector.
Public assistance includes government-backed programs offering subsidies to promote restaurant growth and development within communities.

Mediterranean restaurants in the US are subject to health and safety regulations set by local health departments, ensuring food handling, sanitation, and kitchen safety standards. There are also regulations concerning permits and licenses for food preparation that vary by state and municipality.

Profit margins in the Mediterranean restaurant industry have decreased from 5.1% to 4.7%, emphasizing the importance of managing operational costs while maintaining quality. Balancing competitive prices and affordable ingredients can help control expenses.

Full-service dining in Mediterranean restaurants has experienced a resurgence, emphasizing personalized service, attention to detail, and authentic cooking methods. These establishments attract individuals who enjoy an inviting atmosphere fitting for special occasions or social gatherings.

Mediterranean restaurants earn most of their revenue from higher-income households that dine out often. These households prefer establishments that provide personalized service, authentic meals and an upscale atmosphere.

Consumer spending measures individual spending on goods and services by Americans both domestically and abroad. As consumer spending rises, people are more likely to spend money at restaurants, thus driving demand for industry services. When there is an observable rise in consumer spending, it represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: These households belong to a lower-income bracket. Financial constraints usually prevent these households from eating out frequently.
These households fall within a moderate-income bracket, and can afford to dine out occasionally while prioritizing affordability and quality.
These are households of middling to high income with greater disposable income to dine out more frequently.
Businesses seek goods and services to fulfill their operational needs, which occasionally includes providing meals for their employees.
These households belong to a higher income bracket and can afford a more indulgent lifestyle, dining out frequently.

products_and_services.product_description: Full-service dining in Mediterranean restaurants featuring table service and a more formal atmosphere.
Take-out and delivery services allow customers to order food from restaurants for pick-up or home delivery.
Fast casual dining combines the convenience of fast food with a more upscale dining experience, offering fresh and customizable Mediterranean meals.
Upscale dining refers to premium Mediterranean restaurants serving elevated cuisine at a higher price point.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumer spending measures individual spending on goods and services by Americans both domestically and abroad. As consumer spending rises, people are more likely to spend money at restaurants, thus driving demand for industry services.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of Mediterranean restaurant establishments at 33.3%.
The West region has 18.2% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The Mid-Atlantic region has 15.2% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The Great Lakes region has 12.1% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The Southwest region has 9.1% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The Plains region has 6.1% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The New England region has 3% of Mediterranean restaurant establishments.
The Rocky Mountain region has the lowest percentage of Mediterranean restaurant establishments at 3%.

basis_points.basis_description: High initial capital investment in quality ingredients and skilled staff, coupled with intense competition in the food service market, make entry difficult for new Mediterranean restaurants.
Establishing a unique identity in a saturated market amidst comparable establishments can be a significant challenge.
Suppliers wield considerable influence on Mediterranean restaurants, influencing menu offerings and the output of a restaurant.
Mediterranean restaurants rely on consistent delivery of fresh fish and produce, as the quality and authenticity of ingredients directly impacts a restaurant's success.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Mediterranean restaurant face moderate market concentration, with a mix of independent eateries and regional chains dominating various local markets.
While some areas may have a few dominant players, others foster a diverse landscape of smaller, specialized establishments.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit depends on how operational costs are managed
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit margins have fallen from 5.1% of industry revenue in 2019 to 4.7% in 2024. Profit growth depends on a restaurant's ability to manage expenses without compromising on quality. Balancing competitive prices with quality ingredients is a crucial aspect of controlling costs, which is made much easier due to the use of affordable ingredients.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled and kitchen staff require fair wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like other food service establishments, Mediterranean restaurants rely on skilled kitchen staff and experienced servers, as well as managers and other general support staff. Amid the pandemic, a wave of lay-offs and labor shortages hit the food service industry. Temporary closures and capacity limitations forced many restaurants to furlough employees to reduce costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs vary depending on the size and location of a restaurant
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Mediterranean restaurants rely on the use of fresh, high-quality ingredients like olive oil, seafood and produce, which can inflate expenses but contribute greatly to customer satisfaction. Negotiating favorable terms with suppliers, buying in bulk for cost efficiencies, and maintaining consistent quality in ingredient sourcing affect the overall purchasing cost structure.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Mediterranean Staples Are Being Reimagined Sans Allergens and Animal Byproducts
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: - Introducing tahini made from sesame alternatives like sunflower or pumpkin seeds caters to customers with nut allergies. - Seed-based tahini alternatives maintain the creamy texture and nutty flavor essential in Mediterranean cuisine, ensuring inclusivity for those with nut restrictions. - Crafting vegan feta and labneh using alternatives like nuts, tofu or coconut mimics the taste and texture of traditional feta, appealing to vegan and dairy-sensitive customers. - Traditional desserts like baklava made without gluten or nut-based ingredients are somewhat rare, and creating some ensures dessert options for patrons with allergies, celiac disease, or dietary restrictions.

volatility_points.volatility_title: In response to the pandemic, operators had to make additional purchases to comply with added government regulations and adapt to related restrictions.
volatility_points.volatility_description: Purchases are the largest cost for industry operators, accounting for 40.3% of revenue in 2024, down from 39.8% in 2019.

FAQs.question: What were the impacts of the pandemic on Mediterranean restaurants?
FAQs.answer: The pandemic created supply chain disruptions that affected availability of key ingredients used in Mediterranean cooking, such as high-quality olive oil and fresh seafood. Shortages in essential ingredients impacted menu availability and pricing, leading to inconsistent menu offerings.

FAQs.question: How did supply chain disruptions affect profit margins for Mediterranean restaurants?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuating costs due to supply chain disruptions affected profit margins, forcing adjustments in pricing.

FAQs.question: What difficult decision did restaurateurs face regarding pricing?
FAQs.answer: Restaurateurs faced the difficult decision of balancing the need to mitigate profit loss with the potential risk of alienating customers through price increases.

FAQs.question: What was the level of regulation in the industry?
FAQs.answer: The level of regulation was described as LOW or STEADY, but no specific details were provided.
